attributes.alt: Book cover for Hiking Day by Anne Rockwell and illustrated by Lizzy Rockwell. The cover art shows a girl and her father hiking to the top of a mountain.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, sing a song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
How does the girl get ready for her hike  up Hickory Hill?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Ask and answer questions about a text; Share observations about events.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs.
Cooperate and work as a team toward a shared goal.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Invite children to look at pictures and tell what the people are getting ready to do.
Encourage children to respond in complete sentences.
What can we do better together?
What kinds of trees do you  see in that book? What time of year is it?
What can you pretend to do outside with a friend?
How can you sort toys with a friend into toys made of wood and toys made of plastic?
Share a story about going  on a trip or a long walk.
Draw a picture of things you would see if you went for a hike up a mountain.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
What materials can you use to make a path for hiking?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Hiking Day by Anne Rockwell and illustrated by Lizzy Rockwell. The cover art shows a girl and her father hiking to the top of a mountain.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder  to
Read closely to notice and talk about the  Mind Builder.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Cooperate and work as a team toward a shared goal.
Explore geography tools and resources, such as maps, signs, and street addresses.
Have children look at pictures of people working together and say what is happening in the picture.
Challenge children to tell how the people are working together.
What can we do better together?
How are the people in your book working together?
Pretend you are on a hike up a mountain with your friends.
Name three animals you might see on a hike.
Can you write about something you do together with your family at home?
Can you make a tree you would see on a hike up a mountain?
What letter is at the beginning  of the word
Can you build a mountain out  of blocks?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Hiking Day by Anne Rockwell and illustrated by Lizzy Rockwell. The cover art shows a girl and her father hiking to the top of a mountain.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill
What do the girl and her parents see as they climb Hickory Hill?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Cooperate and work as a team toward a shared goal.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.
Have children look at pictures and say if the family in the book saw this animal on their hike.
Encourage children to discuss animals that live in the woods.
What can we do better together?
How are the trees in those books the same? How are they different?
Pretend you are working with a friend to build a house.
Can you compare the size of two animals? Which is taller? Which weighs more? How do you know?
Can you share a story you  wrote with a friend? Can you illustrate it?
Can you imagine a farm with your favorite animals? Can you share that with a friend?
Can you write a letter in a friend’s name? Can you write it in uppercase? Now can you write it in lowercase?
How can you make a vegetable garden with a friend using blocks?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for We Have Soup! The chart says, We have peas. We have corn. We have carrots. Hooray for vegetable soup!

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas:  We Have Soup!

attributes.alt: Book cover for Hiking Day by Anne Rockwell and illustrated by Lizzy Rockwell. The cover art shows a girl and her father hiking to the top of a mountain.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background about  working together and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to this week’s Concept Question,
What can we do better together?
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Cooperate and work as a team toward a shared goal.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.
Help children differentiate between vegetables that grow above and below the ground.
Help children explore the growing season of crops.
What can we do better together?
Can you find examples of people working together in your book?
Pretend you are picking corn. Now you’re pulling onions out  of the ground.
Compare how two vegetables are the same and different.
Which vegetables would you want in a soup? Can you write about it?
Can you draw a picture of a  delicious bowl of soup that you might make?
Can you show me what letter makes the beginning sound you hear in the word
Can you build a vegetable stand where you can sell vegetables?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Hiking Day by Anne Rockwell and illustrated by Lizzy Rockwell. The cover art shows a girl and her father hiking to the top of a mountain.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children act out scenes from
What happens when they reach the  top of Hickory Hill?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Cooperate and work as a team toward a shared goal.
Try a new approach or new tasks; Talk and share.
Share and celebrate written products; Independently write letters to make words  or word parts.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
What are three things that we can do better with a friend?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What can we do better together?
Tell a story to a friend about trying to do something new.
Pretend you are climbing a tall mountain.
Can you work together to leap from a starting point and measure how far you jump?
Can you create a story about  a friendly toad?
Can you imagine something that you’d like to do that you never did before? What would it be?
What is the letter at the beginning of the word
How would you build a home for one of the animals in the book? What materials would you use?

Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than used.

Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.

Observe, investigate, describe and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
